verses.text: The words of the Teacher, son of David, king in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Identifies the speaker as the 'Teacher' (Hebrew: Qoheleth), traditionally understood to be Solomon. No change from the usual meaning.

verses.text: "Vanity of vanities," says the Teacher, "Vanity of vanities! All is vanity."
verses.comment: 'Vanity' (Hebrew: hebel) expresses emptiness or futility. The repetition emphasizes the all-encompassing nature of life's transience.

verses.text: What does man gain by all the labor with which he toils under the sun?
verses.comment: 'Under the sun' is a key phrase throughout the book, highlighting a perspective limited to earthly life.

verses.text: A generation goes, and a generation comes, but the earth remains forever.
verses.comment: The transience of human life is contrasted with the enduring creation, echoing themes of mortality versus stability.

verses.text: The sun rises, and the sun sets; and hurries back to the place where it rises.
verses.comment: The repetitive cycle of nature serves as a metaphor for the endless cycles of human existence.

verses.text: The wind blows toward the south and turns to the north; round and round it goes, ever returning on its circuit.
verses.comment: Nature's endless cycles hint at the Creator's order, yet they also underline limitations of understanding apart from revelation.

verses.text: All streams run to the sea, yet the sea is never full; to the place where the streams flow, there they flow again.
verses.comment: Natural cycles reflect the persistence of creation, but also the tendency toward futility in the absence of ultimate fulfillment.

verses.text: All things are wearisome; more than one can say. The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.
verses.comment: Human desire and curiosity are never fully satisfied in this life, suggesting a longing for something beyond earthly experience.

verses.text: What has been is what will be, and what has been done is what will be done; there is nothing new under the sun.
verses.comment: The 'nothing new' captures the cyclical and repetitive nature of earthly history, fostering humility about our accomplishments.

verses.text: Is there a thing of which it is said, 'See, this is new'? It has been already, in ages before us.
verses.comment: Despite technological progress, the Teacher reminds readers that human nature and existential realities remain unchanged.

verses.text: There is no remembrance of former things, nor will there be any remembrance of later things yet to be among those who come after.
verses.comment: Transience and forgetfulness speak to the ultimate impermanence of human achievements and the need for lasting meaning.

verses.text: I, the Teacher, have been king over Israel in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Reinforces Solomonic authorship and authority as a source of wisdom.

verses.text: I applied my heart to seek and to search out by wisdom all that is done under heaven. It is a burdensome task that God has given to the sons of man to be afflicted with.
verses.comment: The reference to the 'burdensome task' echoes the consequence of the fall, seen in Genesis, and humankind's longing for restored wisdom. The role of God is direct, implying that only divine revelation offers true answers (cf. 1 Cor. 1:18-24).

verses.text: I have seen all the works that are done under the sun, and behold, all is vanity and striving after wind.
verses.comment: 'Striving after wind' is an image for ultimate futility apart from lasting purpose—preparing the reader for the Gospel’s message of true fulfillment in Christ.

verses.text: What is crooked cannot be made straight, and what is lacking cannot be counted.
verses.comment: This phrase alludes to the reality of fallen human nature. Later scripture promises that God alone can make the crooked straight—a theme ultimately realized in Christ.

verses.text: I said to myself, 'I have acquired great wisdom, surpassing all who were over Jerusalem before me, and my heart has had great experience of wisdom and knowledge.'
verses.comment: Solomon's reputation for wisdom is referenced as validation for the Teacher's reflections.

verses.text: And I applied my heart to know wisdom, and to know madness and folly. I perceived that this also is a striving after wind.
verses.comment: This pursuit of wisdom, even at its best, is limited without divine guidance, hinting that human reason alone cannot reach ultimate truth—thus preparing for the later biblical teaching on grace.

verses.text: For in much wisdom is much sorrow, and he who increases knowledge increases pain.
verses.comment: While wisdom is valued elsewhere in Scripture, here the Teacher exposes its limits apart from the fullness of divine revelation. This theme finds its answer in the person of Christ, the incarnate Wisdom (John 14:6).
